I was under the (perhaps flawed) impression that matter had no volume.
For instance, if I take a bunch of electrically neutral particles and organize them into a newton's cradle that's one light year long, and then hit one side of it, the particles cannot deform to carry energy (because that would imply that they're made of other stuff that can have momentum so they are not actually particles), the particles cannot teleport the energy faster than the speed of light, and the model cannot destroy energy or momentum. So... I can't build a newton's craddle out of particles then. I just can't. Not only that, I can't even play billard with particles, because that's fundamentally the same thing as a newton's craddle. Two particles cannot "hit" each other because that would contradict the laws of physics or prove that they aren't in fact true particles.
So... is it that we can't "hit particles against each other"? Well... maybe somehow it would take infinite energy to put them in close enough proximity with each other, but that's not exactly satisfying is it... Because the force exerted is always equal proportionally to 1/d^2. So, only a distance of 0 between the actual centers of mass of the particles would actually demand infinite energy, implying that the only way this restriction works is if the particles have a radius of zero.

Let's imagine a pool of liquid and a sheet of fabric placed over it. If nothing is happening - nothing is happening. And if they get enough constructive interferense to reach the sheet of fabric, a drop may stay on the fabric for some time. It may then drop off. may stey thar forever. Or move somwhere sideways. Or interact with other drops.

If that analogy is correct, then our 3-d space (or 4-d spacetime maybe) is this fabric. And the field is something existing on a close, but parallel layer of a superspace that has more dimentions. This video is misleading. What it calls "matter" doesn't account for most mass we encounter. Fermions (the half-spin particles subject to Pauli Exclusion and thus can't occupy the same state) are only a small portion of that mass. The majority of mass comes from gluon interactions. Sorry for using such an absurd example; I just find it easier to think about in terms of extremes.  A more realistic example would be proving the ideal gas law; you need several assumptions, including that particles take up no space in themselves (not true) and that they don't interact.

I'd just like to add that mathematical proof is perfectly accurate... within the assumptions used.  So when using maths to prove a physical model, you'll (almost?) always be making huge sweeping assumptions that make your result imperfect, but a nice balance of accurate and simple enough to be useful.  If somehow by assuming I'm a bar of soap I find that electrons are made of chocolate, the proof is still valid, but the assumption is not true, so the outcome might or might not be.

Strictly speaking, a quantum state is described by a vector in Hilbert space. In "layman", a quantum state is a mathematical expression containing all the statistical information about a particle. For each electron around an atom, the expression contains 4 quantum numbers, which distinguishes them. The Pauli exclusion principle is an observed fact fully explained in quantum mechanics: No electrons around an atom can have the same quantum numbers. Google these terms for a deeper understanding.

Basically... electrons can only be in the same orbital if they have opposite spins. According to the Aufbau principle, electrons tend to fill up each orbital of a sublevel with one electron before they start putting themselves together. For example, in the p sublevel, there are 3 possible orbitals, which means a maximum of 6 electrons. There would have to be more than 3 electrons in the sublevel for them to start doubling up in any orbital.

There are two ways of making this work. Because you get probabilities from squaring the wavefunction, either the wavefunction inverts under particle exchange, or it doesn't. If it inverts, it goes to zero when you try to put the electrons on top of each other. If it doesn't invert, it grows when you put two particles together, which is why bosons actually like sitting in the same state.

In a BEC, the composite particles like sitting together, so if you cool them they collapse to the same state.

It's easier to understand 'identical' if you think about it in terms of particle swapping. The location of an electron isn't precisely defined; the wavefunction extends over space, so you can't really say exactly where the electron is. If you have two electrons nearby, and you look at them, and look at them a while later, you don't know if they switched places or not. Because you can't tell, you need to consider both possibilities when you consider each electron.

Actually they can. Bosons (photons, gluons etc.) may always "share the same space" (a notion which in itself is very delicate to use in quantum mechanics), whereas fermions (electrons, neutrons etc.) may only share space if they are in different quantum states. It's because we're made of so many fermions in the same quantum state that we can't be at the same place!
In other words, electrons can be identical as long as they're not in the same place at the same time.

The main difference between these two groups is that bosons do not obey the Pauli Exclusion Principle (which is explained in this video). Therefore photons, which are bosons, can occupy the same quantum state and thus they are not matter. (Photons are the particles which carry light btw)

No, light is not matter. Light is made up of photons. Photons are commonly misrepresented as "packets" of energy or light, when in reality they are an electric field which collapses and results in a magnetic field, which collapses back into an electric field. The rate of this oscillation between fields determines the frequency of the light. Also, these fields are only two dimensional, with no dimension in the direction of their travel, which explains why they are massless. So there you go :)
